results.title: A Plain and sacred right
results.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Encounters”.
Looks at why Aboriginal people feel so strongly about their struggle for land rights. Filmed mainly at Noonkanbah, the scene of bitter Aboriginal demonstrations of 1980, the program looks at what Aboriginal people are now doing to preserve their traditional way of life. Tribal Aboriginals explain their bond with the land and put their views on white society.

group_siblings.title: The Broken covenant
group_siblings.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC

results.title: Settle down country
results.creator_credit: Pam Nathan, Jim Buckell, David Batty, NAIHO, CAAMA, CAAC and Western Deserts Oustations Council
results.brief_description: Documents the return of the Pintubi people to their own lands after many years on Government run settlements. Extensive use of archival footage offers an added historical perspective to this account of the efforts of these people to retain their cultural heritage. Based on the book of the same name by Dick Leichleitner Japanangka and Pam Nathan.

results.title: Aboriginal bark painting
results.creator_credit: Latrobe University. School of Education. Media Centre
results.brief_description: Made in partnership with the Barinaga Aboriginal Co-operative at Maningrida, Northern Territory. Provides an informative look at the bark paintings of Arnhem Land, placing the art work firmly in the context of Aboriginal belief systems and using traditional techniques. A useful complement to “The art and craft of Maningrida”. Narrated by Robin Cuming.

results.title: Desert stories
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Frazer, Nick Frazer, Channel 0-28 and KOKO P
results.brief_description: The Pintubi Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory tell stories of the Dreamtime, and other stories of their lives. Also shows the work of the Papunya Aboriginal Settlement Literature Production Centre in recording the Pintubi people in their own language. Care is taken that the oral tradition is retained, when transcribing the stories.

results.title: Tracks of the rainbow
results.creator_credit: George Gittoes, Gabrielle Dalton and Gittoes and Dalton Productions
results.brief_description: The filmed journey of six Aboriginal teenagers as they travel from the southern urbanised areas of Australia, where memories of tribal life are disappearing, to the wild north of Australia in search of the traditional ways of their people. The Dreamtime Rainbow Serpent is their symbolic guide as they follow its epic tracks from Ayers Rock, north through Arnhem Land and across the sea to Melville Island.

results.title: Familiar places
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Shows the recent movement of Aboriginal people back to their traditional lands. As this movement has grown Aborigines have seen the importance of mapping their land, and we see anthropologist Peter Sutton helping them. Peter Sutton provides a commentary on what he has learned about Aboriginal ties to the land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: Takeover
results.creator_credit: Judith MacDougall, David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: On 13th March, 1978 the Queensland government announced its intention to take over the management of the Aurukun Aboriginal Reserve from the Uniting Church. The people of Aurukun complained bitterly, believing that the Church was more sympathetic to their aims and fearing that the State was merely seeking easier access to the rich bauxite deposits on their Reserve. When the Federal Government took the side of the Aborigines the stage was set for national confrontation. Shows the situation at Aurukun during those crucial three weeks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judith MacDougall, David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

When the Federal Government took the side of the Aborigines the stage was set for national confrontation. Shows the situation at Aurukun during those crucial three weeks.

results.title: Sons of Namatjira
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Keith Namatjira and his relatives paint in the style of his father, Albert and live in an artist’s camp set up by his father on the outskirts of Alice Springs. Highlights problems which the Namatjiras and Aborigines in general have to confront in their relationship with the world outside the community.

results.title: The House-opening
results.creator_credit: Judith MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: The house-opening ceremony performed at Aurukun is derived from traditional mortuary rites, but European and Torres Strait Island elements are now combined with these in a ceremony which at times assumes the atmosphere of a party. Traditionally, when someone died their house was burned, but with the advent of European-style housing this practice became impractical and the house-opening was developed as a means of ritually purifying the house so that the family may re-inhabit it.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judith MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: They used to call it sandy blight
results.creator_credit: Douglas Stanley and Nomad Films International
results.brief_description: Designed to reveal the problem of trachoma and other serious eye diseases common to outback Aborigines. Health problems, housing and general living conditions are also looked at. Shows how medical attention can help to alleviate problems.
